For some camcorder versions of movies you're satisfied with the results but for this particular recording, you're going to want to watch it again in a few months when it releases to DVD and BluRay if you're interested in hearing the dialogue, because you're going to struggle to hear what is being said throughout the entire movie. The first two and a half minutes feature absolutely no sound and before it kicks in I would suggest turning down your volume.

I noticed with the fight scenes that the sound would go out sync and it's very dark in many of the scenes, too. I tried turning up the brightness in the video player but this didn't help much. The movie seems good from what I was able to see and comprehend, but I wouldn't really rate it anything until you see it once more on something of a higher quality. It would make the movie much more enjoyable.

@palerm0 The theaters in your area might be the ones setting the price, but they are not to be blamed completely. They have to pay the Studios the rights to the movie, they have to pay their employees, the electric bill to power all the protectors, and etc.

And there are always Matinee prices; movie shown during the day, and in some theaters all day Sunday cost less than movie shown at night. Here day time is $5-6 depending on theater and night showings are $9-11 (again depending on theater) Also there are Student discounts; Some schools don't have Student IDs - But there are sites that tell you how to make them; or http://www.homeschoolbuyersco-op.org/homeschool-id/ which you can just buy one for $7 - thats what I did for my girl since I'm a college student and she is not; Theaters here limit 1 ticket per student ID.
